data.title: Nicholas Brown (abt.1642-aft.1711)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Explore genealogy for Nicholas Brown born abt. 1642 Portsmouth, Newport, Rhode Island died 1711 Shrewsbury, Monmouth, Middlesex, New Jersey including parents + descendants + 1 genealogist comments + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Descendants

Profile last modified 27 Jul 2023 | Created 7 Feb 2011

This page has been accessed 1,253 times.

Biography

Birth

Nicholas was born about 1642. His father was Nicholas Brown of Portsmouth, Rhode Island. He was left a bequeathment in his father's Will.

"NICHOLAS BROWN (JR.) (2) son of NICHOLAS Brown (1) was of Shark River (NJ) where he d. abt. 1714. He took the Oath in 1668 and was appointed Ensign by the Dutch in 1673. In 1683 he brought an action against Capt. Christopher Almy. He was 3 times married. [1]

Marriages

Unknown. [1]

Katherine Almy, widow Bartholomew West (his 2nd wf.) she d. 1703. [1]

Mary Chambers. By 3rd m. had dau. Mary b. 25 Aug 1710 who m. Daniel Seabrook. [1]

On October 18, 1671, Nicholas Browne of New Jersey was indicted by the Grand Jury at the General Court of Trials at Newport for fornication with Martha Hicks (now wife of Lawrence Springand) of Portsmouth. He pleaded not guilty, and the court found him not guilty of fornication. Martha confessed guilty, and was fined 40 shillings.[2]

By 1685 Nicholas Brown was residing in Shrewsbury, Essex County, New Jersey. [3]

On 18 July 1688 "Nicholas 'Browne' of Shrewsbury made a Bond to prosecute the caveat against granting to Jedidiah Allen a patent for 30 acres at G____ Neck." [4]

Death and Will

Nicholas Brown died in 1711 at Shrewsbury, Monmouth, New Jersey. Will of Nicholas Brown Sr (1615-1694) was probated 2 Feb 1711. [5]

1711/2 Feb.21 Brown. Nicholas of Shrewsbury, Monmouth Co., Gent.; Will of. Wife Mary executrix, dau. Mary heiress after mother's death of the home farm on Shrewsbury River, unless another child be born. Witnesses-Hannah Chambers, Preserve Lippincott, Samuel Williams, William Hulet, Jr., Sam. Dennes, Jr., Will Proved 2 Jun 1719. {Lib. I, p.480].

1714 Apr 26. Inventory of the personal estate (L95.11.7, incl. a neagro man and an old neagrowoman, L20), made by Jeremiah Stillwell and Joseph Haviland Sworn to by Mary, the widow and executrix of Nicholas, Jul 9, 1714.

Nicholas's daughter Mary married Daniel Seabrook. On 30 August 1740, Daniel Seabrook of Middletown, yeoman, and Mary his wife "sole heir unto her father Nicholas Brown late of the town of Shewsbury" sold land at Shrewsbury to John Chambers of Shrewsbury, yeoman, said land being part of a tract patented to Nicholas Brown in 1688.[6] Daniel and Mary then appeared and acknowledged the deed on 31 July 1747.

Sources

↑ 1.0 1.1 1.2 1.3 Book Page Image: This Old Monmouth of Ours: Author: William S. Horner; Moreau Brothers Publishers @ Freehold, NJ, Date: 1932. Pg. 206
